754
755    /**
756     * Gets the alpha channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
757     * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #hsluv(float, float, float, float)}
758     * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the alpha channel value of the given encoded color
759     */
760    public static float alpha(final float encoded)
761    {
762        return (BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) >>> 25) / 127f;
763    }
764
765
766    /**
767     * Gets the "chroma" or "colorfulness" of a given HSLuv color. Chroma is similar to saturation in that grayscale
768     * values have 0 saturation and 0 chroma, while brighter colors have high saturation and chroma. The difference is
769     * that colors that are perceptually more-colorful have higher chroma than colors that are perceptually
770     * less-colorful, regardless of hue, whereas saturation changes its meaning depending on the hue and lightness. That
771     * is, the most saturated color for a given hue and lightness always has a saturation of 1, but if that color
772     * isn't perceptually very colorful (as is the case for very dark and very light colors), it will have a chroma that
773     * is much lower than the maximum. The result of this method can't be negative, grayscale values have very close to
774     * 0 chroma, and the most colorful value (a shade of purple) should have ??? chroma.
775     * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #hsluv(float, float, float, float)}
776     * @return a float between 0.0f and ??? that represents how colorful the given value is
777     */
778    public static float chroma(final float encoded) {
779        final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
780        float H = ((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
781        float S = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) / 255f);
782        float L = reverseLight((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) / 255f);
783
784        // HSLuv to Lch
785        if (L > 0.99999f) {
786            return 0f;
787        } else if (L < 0.00001f) {
788            return 0f;
789        } else
790            return chromaLimit(H, L) * S;
791    }
792    /**
793     * Given a hue and lightness, this gets the (exact) maximum chroma possible for that hue-lightness
794     * combination, using HSLuv's versions of lightness and hue (not raw HSL). This is useful to know the bounds of
795     * {@link #chroma(float)}. This should be no greater than 1.0f . Note that this version of chromaLimit() is
796     * a little slower than Oklab's version, because this has to go to greater lengths to become accurate.
797     * @param hue the hue, typically between 0.0f and 1.0f, to look up
798     * @param lightness the lightness, clamped between 0.0f and 1.0f, to look up
799     * @return the maximum possible chroma for the given hue and lightness, between 0.0f and 1.0f
800     */
801    public static float chromaLimit(final float hue, final float lightness) {
802        final float h = hue - floor(hue);
803        float sin = TrigTools.sinTurns(h);
804        float cos = TrigTools.cosTurns(h);
805        float sub1 = (lightness + 0.16f) / 1.16f;
806        sub1 *= sub1 * sub1;
807        float sub2 = sub1 > epsilon ? sub1 : lightness / kappa;
808        float min = Float.MAX_VALUE;
809        for (int i = 0; i < 3; i++) {
810            float m1 = m[i][0] * sub2, m2 = m[i][1] * sub2, m3 = m[i][2] * sub2;
811            for (int t = 0; t < 2; t++) {
812                m2 -= t;
813                float top1 = 2845.17f * m1 - 948.39f * m3;
814                float top2 = (8384.22f * m3 + 7698.60f * m2 + 7317.18f * m1) * lightness;
815                float bottom = (6322.60f * m3 - 1264.52f * m2);
816                float length = intersectLength(sin, cos, top1 / bottom, top2 / bottom);
817                if (length >= 0) min = Math.min(min, length);
818            }
819        }
820        return min;
821    }
822
823    private static float intersectLength (float sin, float cos, float line1, float line2) {
824        return line2 / (sin - line1 * cos);
825    }
826
827    /**
828     * Gets the color with the same L as the HSLuv color stored in the given packed float, but the furthest A
829     * B from gray possible for that lightness while keeping the same hue as the given color. This is very
830     * similar to calling {@link #enrich(float, float)} with a very large {@code change} value.
831     * @param packed a packed float color in HSLuv format; does not need to be in-gamut
832     * @return the color that is as far from grayscale as this can get while keeping the L and hue of packed
833     * @see #limitToGamut(float) You can use limitToGamut() if you only want max saturation for out-of-gamut colors.
834     */
835    public static float maximizeSaturation(final float packed) {
836        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed) | 0x0000FF00);
837    }
838    /**
839     * Gets the color with the given H, L, and alpha, but ignores the given S and instead uses the furthest S
840     * from gray possible for that lightness while keeping the same hue as the given color. This is very
841     * similar to calling {@link #enrich(float, float)} with a very large {@code change} value.
842     * @param H hue component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
843     * @param S saturation; ignored, and will always be maximized
844     * @param L lightness component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
845     * @param alpha alpha component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
846     * @return the color that is as far from grayscale as this can get while keeping the H and L of packed
847     */
848    public static float maximizeSaturation(float H, float S, float L, float alpha) {
849        return clamp(H, 1f, L, alpha);
850    }
851
852    /**
853     * Gets the hue of the given HSLuv float color, but as HSLuv understands hue rather than how HSL does.
854     * This is different from {@link #hue(float)}, which uses HSL. This gives a float between 0 (inclusive)
855     * and 1 (exclusive).
856     * <br>
857     * This is the same as {@link #channelH(float)}.
858     *
859     * @param packed a packed HSLuv float color
860     * @return a float between 0 (inclusive) and 1 (exclusive) that represents hue in the HSLuv color space
861     */
862    public static float hsluvHue(final float packed) {
863        return (BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed) & 0xff) / 255f;
864    }
865
866    /**
867     * Gets the saturation of the given HSLuv float color, but as HSLuv understands saturation rather than how HSL
868     * does. Saturation here is a fraction of the chroma limit (see {@link #chromaLimit(float, float)}) for a given hue
869     * and lightness, and is between 0 and 1. This gives a float between 0 (inclusive) and 1 (inclusive).
870     * <br>
871     * This is the same as {@link #channelS(float)}.
872     *
873     * @param packed a packed HSLuv float color
874     * @return a float between 0 (inclusive) and 1 (inclusive) that represents saturation in the HSLuv color space
875     */
876    public static float hsluvSaturation(final float packed) {
877        return (BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed) >>> 8 & 0xff) / 255f;
878    }
879    /**
880     * Gets the lightness of the given HSLuv float color, but as HSLuv understands lightness rather than how HSL does.
881     * This is different from {@link #lightness(float)}, which uses HSL. This gives a float between 0 (inclusive)
882     * and 1 (inclusive).
883     * <br>
884     * This is the same as {@link #channelL(float)}.
885     *
886     * @param packed a packed HSLuv float color
887     * @return a float between 0 (inclusive) and 1 (inclusive) that represents lightness in the HSLuv color space
888     */
889    public static float hsluvLightness(final float packed){
890        return (BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed) >>> 16 & 0xff) / 255f;
891    }
892
893    /**
894     * A different way to specify a HSLuv color, using hue, chroma, lightness, and alpha something like a normal HSL(A)
895     * color but calculating them directly in the HSLuv color space. This has you specify the desired chroma directly,
896     * as obtainable with {@link #chroma(float)}, rather than the saturation, which is a fraction of the maximum chroma.
897     * Note that this takes a different value for its {@code hue} that the method {@link #hue(float)} produces, just
898     * like {@code lightness} and the method {@link #lightness(float)}. The hue is just distributed differently, and the
899     * lightness should be equivalent to {@link #channelL(float)}. If you use this to get two colors with the same
900     * chroma and lightness, but different hue, then the resulting colors should have similar colorfulness unless one or
901     * both chroma values exceeded the gamut limit (you can get this limit with {@link #chromaLimit(float, float)}). If
902     * a chroma value given is greater than the chroma limit, this clamps chroma to that limit. You can use
903     * {@link #hsluvHue(float)}, {@link #chroma(float)}, and {@link #hsluvLightness(float)} to get the hue, chroma, and
904     * lightness values from an existing color that this will understand ({@link #alpha(float)} too).
905     * @param hue between 0 and 1, usually, but this will automatically wrap if too high or too low
906     * @param chroma will be clamped between 0 and the maximum chroma possible for the given hue and lightness
907     * @param lightness will be clamped between 0 and 1
908     * @param alpha will be clamped between 0 and 1
909     * @return a packed HSLuv float color that tries to match the requested hue, chroma, and lightness
910     */
911    public static float hsluvByHCL(float hue, float chroma, float lightness, float alpha) {
912        hue -= floor(hue);
913        alpha = Math.min(Math.max(alpha, 0f), 1f);
914        if(lightness <= 0f) return hsluv(hue, 0f, 0f, alpha);
915        if(lightness >= 1f) return hsluv(hue, 0f, 1f, alpha);
916        return hsluv(hue, Math.max(chroma, 0f) / (chromaLimit(hue, lightness) + 0.0001f), lightness, alpha);
917    }
918
919    /**
920     * Gets a color as a HSLuv packed float given floats representing HSL hue, saturation, lightness, and opacity.
921     * You should usually prefer just using {@link #hsluv(float, float, float, float)} to get colors with these values.
922     * All parameters should normally be between 0 and 1 inclusive, though any hue is tolerated (precision loss may
923     * affect the color if the hue is too large). A hue of 0 is red, progressively higher hue values go to orange,
924     * yellow, green, blue, and purple before wrapping around to red as it approaches 1. A saturation of 0 is grayscale,
925     * a saturation of 1 is brightly colored, and values close to 1 will usually appear more distinct than values close
926     * to 0, especially if the hue is different. A lightness of 0.001f or less is always black (also using a shortcut if
927     * this is the case, respecting opacity), while a lightness of 1f is white. Very bright colors are mostly in a band
928     * of high-saturation where lightness is 0.5f.
929     *
930     * @param hue        0f to 1f, color wheel position
931     * @param saturation 0f to 1f, 0f is grayscale and 1f is brightly colored
932     * @param lightness  0f to 1f, 0f is black and 1f is white
933     * @param opacity    0f to 1f, 0f is fully transparent and 1f is opaque
934     * @return a HSLuv float encoding a color with the given properties
935     */
936    public static float floatGetHSL(float hue, float saturation, float lightness, float opacity) {
937        if (lightness <= 0.001f) {
938            return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((((int) (opacity * 255f) << 24) & 0xFE000000));
939        } else if (lightness >= 0.999f) {
940            return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((((int) (opacity * 255f) << 24) & 0xFE000000) | 0x00FF0000);
941        } else {
942            return fromRGBA(FloatColors.hsl2rgb(hue, saturation, lightness, opacity));
943        }
944    }
945
946    /**
947     * Gets the saturation of the given encoded color as HSL would calculate it, as a float ranging from 0.0f to 1.0f,
948     * inclusive. This is different from {@link #chroma(float)}; see that method's documentation for details.
949     *
950     * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #hsluv(float, float, float, float)}
951     * @return the saturation of the color from 0.0 (a grayscale color; inclusive) to 1.0 (a bright color, inclusive)
952     */
953    public static float saturation(final float encoded) {
954        final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
955        float H = ((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
956        float S = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) / 255f);
957        float L = reverseLight((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) / 255f);
958
959        // HSLuv to Lch
960        float C;
961        if (L > 0.99999f) {
962            L = 1;
963            C = 0;
964        } else if (L < 0.00001f) {
965            L = 0;
966            C = 0;
967        } else
968            C = chromaLimit(H, L) * S;
969
970        // Lch to Luv
971        float U = TrigTools.cosTurns(H) * C;
972        float V = TrigTools.sinTurns(H) * C;
973
974        // Luv to XYZ
975        float x, y, z;
976        if (L < 0.00001f) {
977            x = 0;
978            y = 0;
979            z = 0;
980        } else {
981            if (L <= 0.08f)
982                y = L / kappa;
983            else {
984                y = (L + 0.16f) / 1.16f;
985                y *= y * y;
986            }
987            float iL = 1f / (13f * L);
988            float varU = U * iL + refU;
989            float varV = V * iL + refV;
990            x = 9 * varU * y / (4 * varV);
991            z = (3 * y / varV) - x / 3 - 5 * y;
992        }
993        final float r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z, 0f), 1f));
994        final float g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z, 0f), 1f));
995        final float b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z, 0f), 1f));
996        float X, Y, W;
997        if(g < b) {
998            X = b;
999            Y = g;
1000        }
1001        else {
1002            X = g;
1003            Y = b;
1004        }
1005        if(r < X) {
1006            W = r;
1007        }
1008        else {
1009            W = X;
1010            X = r;
1011        }
1012        return X - Math.min(W, Y);
1013    }
1014
1015    /**
1016     * Defined as per HSL; normally you only need {@link #channelL(float)} to get accurate lightness for HSLuv. This
1017     * ranges from 0.0f (black) to 1.0f (white).
1018     *
1019     * @param encoded a packed float HSLuv color
1020     * @return the lightness of the given color as HSL would calculate it
1021     */
1022    public static float lightness(final float encoded) {
1023        final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
1024        float H = ((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
1025        float S = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) / 255f);
1026        float L = reverseLight((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) / 255f);
1027
1028        // HSLuv to Lch
1029        float C;
1030        if (L > 0.99999f) {
1031            L = 1;
1032            C = 0;
1033        } else if (L < 0.00001f) {
1034            L = 0;
1035            C = 0;
1036        } else
1037            C = chromaLimit(H, L) * S;
1038
1039        // Lch to Luv
1040        float U = TrigTools.cosTurns(H) * C;
1041        float V = TrigTools.sinTurns(H) * C;
1042
1043        // Luv to XYZ
1044        float x, y, z;
1045        if (L < 0.00001f) {
1046            x = 0;
1047            y = 0;
1048            z = 0;
1049        } else {
1050            if (L <= 0.08f)
1051                y = L / kappa;
1052            else {
1053                y = (L + 0.16f) / 1.16f;
1054                y *= y * y;
1055            }
1056            float iL = 1f / (13f * L);
1057            float varU = U * iL + refU;
1058            float varV = V * iL + refV;
1059            x = 9 * varU * y / (4 * varV);
1060            z = (3 * y / varV) - x / 3 - 5 * y;
1061        }
1062        final float r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z, 0f), 1f));
1063        final float g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z, 0f), 1f));
1064        final float b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z, 0f), 1f));
1065        float X, Y, W;
1066        if(g < b) {
1067            X = b;
1068            Y = g;
1069        }
1070        else {
1071            X = g;
1072            Y = b;
1073        }
1074        if(r < X) {
1075            W = r;
1076        }
1077        else {
1078            W = X;
1079            X = r;
1080        }
1081        float d = X - Math.min(W, Y);
1082        return X * (1f - 0.5f * d / (X + 1e-10f));
1083    }
1084
1085    /**
1086     * Gets the hue of the given encoded color, as a float from 0f (inclusive, red and approaching orange if increased)
1087     * to 1f (exclusive, red and approaching purple if decreased).
1088     *
1089     * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #hsluv(float, float, float, float)}
1090     * @return The hue of the color from 0.0 (red, inclusive) towards orange, then yellow, and
1091     * eventually to purple before looping back to almost the same red (1.0, exclusive)
1092     */
1093    public static float hue(final float encoded) {
1094        final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
1095        float H = ((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
1096        float S = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) / 255f);
1097        float L = reverseLight((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) / 255f);
1098
1099        // HSLuv to Lch
1100        float C;
1101        if (L > 0.99999f) {
1102            L = 1;
1103            C = 0;
1104        } else if (L < 0.00001f) {
1105            L = 0;
1106            C = 0;
1107        } else
1108            C = chromaLimit(H, L) * S;
1109
1110        // Lch to Luv
1111        float U = TrigTools.cosTurns(H) * C;
1112        float V = TrigTools.sinTurns(H) * C;
1113
1114        // Luv to XYZ
1115        float x, y, z;
1116        if (L < 0.00001f) {
1117            x = 0;
1118            y = 0;
1119            z = 0;
1120        } else {
1121            if (L <= 0.08f)
1122                y = L / kappa;
1123            else {
1124                y = (L + 0.16f) / 1.16f;
1125                y *= y * y;
1126            }
1127            float iL = 1f / (13f * L);
1128            float varU = U * iL + refU;
1129            float varV = V * iL + refV;
1130            x = 9 * varU * y / (4 * varV);
1131            z = (3 * y / varV) - x / 3 - 5 * y;
1132        }
1133        final float r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z, 0f), 1f));
1134        final float g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z, 0f), 1f));
1135        final float b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z, 0f), 1f));
1136        float X, Y, Z, W;
1137        if(g < b) {
1138            X = b;
1139            Y = g;
1140            Z = -1f;
1141            W = 2f / 3f;
1142        }
1143        else {
1144            X = g;
1145            Y = b;
1146            Z = 0f;
1147            W = -1f / 3f;
1148        }
1149        if(r < X) {
1150            Z = W;
1151            W = r;
1152        }
1153        else {
1154            W = X;
1155            X = r;
1156        }
1157        float d = X - Math.min(W, Y);
1158        return Math.abs(Z + (W - Y) / (6f * d + 1e-10f));
1159    }
1160    /**
1161     * Gets a variation on the packed float color basis as another packed float that has its hue, saturation, lightness,
1162     * and opacity adjusted by the specified amounts. Note that this edits the color in HSL space, not HSLuv! Takes
1163     * floats representing the amounts of change to apply to hue, saturation, lightness, and opacity; these can be
1164     * between -1f and 1f. Returns a float that can be used as a packed or encoded color. The float is likely to be
1165     * different from the result of {@code basis} unless hue, saturation, lightness, and opacity are all 0.
1166     * This won't allocate any objects.
1167     * <br>
1168     * The parameters this takes all specify additive changes for a color component, clamping the final values so they
1169     * can't go above 1 or below 0, with an exception for hue, which can rotate around if lower or higher hues would be
1170     * used. As an example, if you give this 0.4f for saturation, and the current color has saturation 0.7f, then the
1171     * resulting color will have 1f for saturation. If you gave this -0.1f for saturation and the current color again
1172     * has saturation 0.7f, then resulting color will have 0.6f for saturation.
1173     *
1174     * @param basis      a packed float color that will be used as the starting point to make the next color
1175     * @param hue        -1f to 1f, the hue change that can be applied to the new float color (not clamped, wraps)
1176     * @param saturation -1f to 1f, the saturation change that can be applied to the new float color
1177     * @param light      -1f to 1f, the light/brightness change that can be applied to the new float color
1178     * @param opacity    -1f to 1f, the opacity/alpha change that can be applied to the new float color
1179     * @return a float encoding a variation of basis with the given changes
1180     */
1181    public static float toEditedFloat(float basis, float hue, float saturation, float light, float opacity) {
1182        final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(basis);
1183        final float li = Math.min(Math.max(light + reverseLight((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) / 255f), 0f), 1f);
1184        opacity = Math.min(Math.max(opacity + (decoded >>> 25) / 127f, 0f), 1f);
1185        if (li <= 0.001f)
1186            return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((((int) (opacity * 255f) << 24) & 0xFE000000));
1187        float H = ((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
1188        float S = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) / 255f);
1189        float L = li;
1190//        float L = (1f/1.16f)*(li + 0.16f);
1191
1192        // HSLuv to Lch
1193        float C;
1194        if (L > 0.99999f) {
1195            L = 1;
1196            C = 0;
1197        } else
1198            C = chromaLimit(H, L) * S;
1199
1200        // Lch to Luv
1201        float U = TrigTools.cosTurns(H) * C;
1202        float V = TrigTools.sinTurns(H) * C;
1203
1204        // Luv to XYZ
1205        float x, y, z;
1206        if (L <= 0.08f)
1207            y = L / kappa;
1208        else {
1209            y = (L + 0.16f) / 1.16f;
1210            y *= y * y;
1211        }
1212        float iL = 1f / (13f * L);
1213        float varU = U * iL + refU;
1214        float varV = V * iL + refV;
1215        x = 9 * varU * y / (4 * varV);
1216        z = (3 * y / varV) - x / 3 - 5 * y;
1217        final float r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z, 0f), 1f));
1218        final float g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z, 0f), 1f));
1219        final float b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z, 0f), 1f));
1220        float X, Y, Z, W;
1221        if(g < b) {
1222            X = b;
1223            Y = g;
1224            Z = -1f;
1225            W = 2f / 3f;
1226        }
1227        else {
1228            X = g;
1229            Y = b;
1230            Z = 0f;
1231            W = -1f / 3f;
1232        }
1233        if(r < X) {
1234            Z = W;
1235            W = r;
1236        }
1237        else {
1238            W = X;
1239            X = r;
1240        }
1241        final float d = X - Math.min(W, Y);
1242        final float lum = X * (1f - 0.5f * d / (X + 1e-10f));
1243        hue += Math.abs(Z + (W - Y) / (6f * d + 1e-10f)) + 1f;
1244        saturation += (X - lum) / (Math.min(lum, 1f - lum) + 1e-10f);
1245        return fromRGBA(FloatColors.hsl2rgb(hue - (int)hue, Math.min(Math.max(saturation, 0f), 1f), lum, opacity));
1246    }
1247
1248
1249    /**
1250     * Given a packed float HSLuv color, this edits its H, S, L, and alpha channels by adding the corresponding "add"
1251     * parameter and then clamping. This returns a different float value (of course, the given float can't be edited
1252     * in-place). You can give a value of 0 for any "add" parameter you want to stay unchanged. H is wrapped, while S,
1253     * L, and alpha are clamped.
1254     * @param encoded a packed float HSLuv color
1255     * @param addH how much to add to the H channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1256     * @param addS how much to add to the S channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1257     * @param addL how much to add to the L channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1258     * @param addAlpha how much to add to the alpha channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1259     * @return a packed float HSLuv color with the requested edits applied to {@code encoded}
1260     */
1261    public static float editHSLuv(float encoded, float addH, float addS, float addL, float addAlpha) {
1262        return editHSLuv(encoded, addH, addS, addL, addAlpha, 1f, 1f, 1f, 1f);
1263    }
1264    /**
1265     * Given a packed float HSLuv color, this edits its H, S, L, and alpha channels by first multiplying each channel
1266     * by the corresponding "mul" parameter and then adding the corresponding "add" parameter, before clamping (this
1267     * wraps H instead of clamping it). This means the lightness value {@code L} is multiplied by {@code mulL}, then has
1268     * {@code addL} added, and then is clamped to the normal range for L (0 to 1). This returns a different float value
1269     * (of course, the given float can't be edited in-place). You can give a value of 0 for any "add" parameter you want
1270     * to stay unchanged, or a value of 1 for any "mul" parameter that shouldn't change. You can multiply S by 0 to make
1271     * a grayscale color, or by a large value to make any non-grayscale color more vibrant. Multiplying H generally
1272     * isn't very useful, but adding to H can be used to do hue cycling (because H wraps).
1273     * @param encoded a packed float HSLuv color
1274     * @param addH how much to add to the H channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1275     * @param addS how much to add to the S channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1276     * @param addL how much to add to the L channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1277     * @param addAlpha how much to add to the alpha channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1278     * @param mulH how much to multiply the H channel by; should be non-negative (not always)
1279     * @param mulS how much to multiply the S channel by; usually non-negative
1280     * @param mulL how much to multiply the L channel by; usually non-negative (not always)
1281     * @param mulAlpha how much to multiply the alpha channel by; should be non-negative
1282     * @return a packed float HSLuv color with the requested edits applied to {@code encoded}
1283     */
1284    public static float editHSLuv(float encoded, float addH, float addS, float addL, float addAlpha,
1285                                  float mulH, float mulS, float mulL, float mulAlpha) {
1286        final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
1287        float H = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
1288        float S = (decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) / 255f;
1289        float L = reverseLight((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) / 255f);
1290        float alpha = (decoded >>> 25) / 127f;
1291
1292        H = H * mulH + addH;
1293        H -= floor(H);
1294        S = Math.min(Math.max(S * mulS + addS, 0f), 1f);
1295        L = Math.min(Math.max(L * mulL + addL, 0f), 1f);
1296        alpha = Math.min(Math.max(alpha * mulAlpha + addAlpha, 0f), 1f);
1297        return hsluv(H, S, L, alpha);
1298    }
1299
1300    /**
1301     * The "H" channel of the given packed float in HSLuv format, which is its hue; ranges from 0.0f to 1.0f .
1302     * You can edit the H of a color with {@link #rotateH(float, float)}.
1303     *
1304     * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #hsluv(float, float, float, float)}
1305     * @return the H value as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
1306     */
1307    public static float channelH(final float encoded)
1308    {
1309        return (BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xff) / 255f;
1310    }
1311
1312    /**
1313     * The "S" channel of the given packed float in HSLuv format, which is its saturation; ranges from 0.0f to
1314     * 1.0f . You can edit the S of a color with {@link #enrich(float, float)} and {@link #dullen(float, float)}.
1315     * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #hsluv(float, float, float, float)}
1316     * @return the S value as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
1317     */
1318    public static float channelS(final float encoded)
1319    {
1320        return ((BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) >>> 8 & 0xff)) / 255f;
1321    }
1322
1323    /**
1324     * The "L" channel of the given packed float in HSLuv format, which is its lightness; ranges from 0.0f to
1325     * 1.0f . You can edit the L of a color with {@link #lighten(float, float)} and {@link #darken(float, float)}.
1326     *
1327     * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #hsluv(float, float, float, float)}
1328     * @return the L value as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
1329     */
1330    public static float channelL(final float encoded)
1331    {
1332        return ((BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) >>> 16 & 0xff)) / 255f;
1333    }
1334
1335    /**
1336     * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards white by change. While change should be between 0f (return
1337     * start as-is) and 1f (return white), start should be a packed color, as from
1338     * {@link #hsluv(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
1339     * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp
1340     * towards white. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha, hue, and
1341     * saturation of start as-is.
1342     * @see #darken(float, float) the counterpart method that darkens a float color
1343     * @param start the starting color as a packed float
1344     * @param change how much to go from start toward white, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to white
1345     * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and white
1346     */
1347    public static float lighten(final float start, final float change) {
1348        final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), t = s >>> 16 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFE00FFFF;
1349        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (t + (0xFF - t) * change) << 16 & 0xFF0000) | other);
1350    }
1351
1352    /**
1353     * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards black by change. While change should be between 0f (return
1354     * start as-is) and 1f (return black), start should be a packed color, as from
1355     * {@link #hsluv(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
1356     * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp
1357     * towards black. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha, hue, and
1358     * saturation of start as-is.
1359     * @see #lighten(float, float) the counterpart method that lightens a float color
1360     * @param start the starting color as a packed float
1361     * @param change how much to go from start toward black, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to black
1362     * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and black
1363     */
1364    public static float darken(final float start, final float change) {
1365        final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), t = s >>> 16 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFE00FFFF;
1366        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (t * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) << 16 | other);
1367    }
1368
1369    /**
1370     * Moves the color of {@code start} away from grayscale by change (saturating the color). While change
1371     * should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return maximally saturated), start should be a packed color, as
1372     * from {@link #hsluv(float, float, float, float)}. This changes only S, and won't change hue, lightness, or alpha.
1373     * @see #dullen(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less saturated
1374     * @param start the starting color as a packed float
1375     * @param change how much to change start to a saturated color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a more saturated result
1376     * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a saturated color
1377     */
1378    public static float enrich(final float start, final float change) {
1379        final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), p = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFF00FF;
1380        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (p + (0xFF - p) * change) << 8 & 0xFF00) | other);
1381    }
1382
1383    /**
1384     * Brings the color of {@code start} closer to grayscale by {@code change} (desaturating the color). While
1385     * change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully gray), start should be a packed color, as
1386     * from {@link #hsluv(float, float, float, float)}. This changes only S, and won't change hue, lightness, or alpha.
1387     * @see #enrich(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more saturated
1388     * @param start the starting color as a packed float
1389     * @param change how much to change start to a desaturated color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a less saturated result
1390     * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a desaturated color
1391     */
1392    public static float dullen(final float start, final float change) {
1393        final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), p = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFF00FF;
1394        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (p * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) << 8 | other);
1395    }
1396
1397    /**
1398     * Cycles the hue of the packed float color by change. If change is 0f, this returns start as-is. If change is
1399     * positive, this rotates from red to orange to yellow to green, and so on. If change is negative, this instead
1400     * rotates from green to yellow to orange to red.  A change value is typically between -1f and 1f; if change is
1401     * exactly an integer, then this will wrap around in a perfect circle and produce no change. The start value should
1402     * be a packed color, as from {@link #hsluv(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations
1403     * of temporary Colors. This only changes H, and won't change saturation, lightness, or alpha.
1404     * @param start the starting color as a packed float
1405     * @param change how much to rotate hue by, as a float typically between -1 and 1; further from 0 rotates more
1406     * @return a packed float that represents a color like start but with a rotated hue
1407     */
1408    public static float rotateH(final float start, final float change) {
1409        final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), i = s & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFFFF00;
1410        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (i + (256f * change)) & 0xFF) | other);
1411    }
1412
1413    /**
1414     * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards that color made opaque by change. While change should be
1415     * between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return start with full alpha), start should be a packed color, as from
1416     * {@link #hsluv(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
1417     * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp
1418     * towards transparent. This won't change the H, S, or L of the color.
1419     * @see #fade(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more translucent
1420     * @param start the starting color as a packed float
1421     * @param change how much to go from start toward opaque, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to opaque
1422     * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and its opaque version
1423     */
1424    public static float blot(final float start, final float change) {
1425        final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), opacity = s >>> 24 & 0xFE, other = s & 0x00FFFFFF;
1426        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (opacity + (0xFE - opacity) * change) & 0xFE) << 24 | other);
1427    }
1428
1429    /**
1430     * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards transparent by change. While change should be between 0
1431     * (return start as-is) and 1f (return the color with 0 alpha), start should be a packed color, as from
1432     * {@link #hsluv(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors,
1433     * and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to
1434     * lerp towards transparent. This won't change the H, S, or L of the color.
1435     * @see #blot(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more opaque
1436     * @param start the starting color as a packed float
1437     * @param change how much to go from start toward transparent, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to transparent
1438     * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and transparent
1439     */
1440    public static float fade(final float start, final float change) {
1441        final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), opacity = s & 0xFE, other = s & 0x00FFFFFF;
1442        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (opacity * (1f - change)) & 0xFE) << 24 | other);
1443    }
1444
1445    /**
1446     * Given a packed float HSLuv color {@code mainColor} and another HSLuv color that it should be made to contrast
1447     * with, gets a packed float HSLuv color with roughly inverted lightness but the same hue, saturation, and alpha.
1448     * This won't ever produce black or other very dark colors, and also has a gap in the range it produces for
1449     * lightness values between 0.5 and 0.55. That allows most of the colors this method produces to contrast well as a
1450     * foreground when displayed on a background of {@code contrastingColor}, or vice versa. This will leave the
1451     * lightness unchanged if the hues of the contrastingColor and those of the mainColor are already very different.
1452     * This has nothing to do with the contrast channel of the tweak in ColorfulBatch; where that part of the tweak can
1453     * make too-similar lightness values further apart by just a little, this makes a modification on {@code mainColor}
1454     * to maximize its lightness difference from {@code contrastingColor} without losing its other qualities.
1455     * @param mainColor a packed float color, as produced by {@link #hsluv(float, float, float, float)}; this is the color that will be adjusted
1456     * @param contrastingColor a packed float color, as produced by {@link #hsluv(float, float, float, float)}; the adjusted mainColor will contrast with this
1457     * @return a different HSLuv packed float color, based on mainColor but with potentially very different lightness
1458     */
1459    public static float inverseLightness(final float mainColor, final float contrastingColor)
1460    {
1461        final int bits = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor),
1462                contrastBits = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(contrastingColor),
1463                H = (bits & 0xff),
1464//                S = (bits >>> 8 & 0xff),
1465                L = (bits >>> 16 & 0xff),
1466                cH = (contrastBits & 0xff),
1467//                cS = (contrastBits >>> 8 & 0xff),
1468                cL = (contrastBits >>> 16 & 0xff);
1469        if(Math.abs(H - cH) >= 90)
1470            return mainColor;
1471        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((bits & 0xFE00FFFF) | (int) (cL < 128 ? L * 0.45f + 128 : 128 - L * 0.45f) << 16);
1472    }
1473
1474    /**
1475     * Given a packed float HSLuv color {@code mainColor} and another HSLuv color that it should be made to contrast
1476     * with, gets a packed float HSLuv color with L that should be quite different from {@code contrastingColor}'s L,
1477     * but the same hue, saturation, and opacity. This allows most of the colors this method produces to contrast well
1478     * as a foreground when displayed on a background of {@code contrastingColor}, or vice versa.
1479     * <br>
1480     * This is similar to {@link #inverseLightness(float, float)}, but is considerably simpler, and this method will
1481     * change the lightness of mainColor when the two given colors have close lightness but distant hues. Because it
1482     * averages the original L of mainColor with the modified one, this tends to not produce harsh color changes.
1483     * @param mainColor a packed HSLuv float color; this is the color that will be adjusted
1484     * @param contrastingColor a packed HSLuv float color; the adjusted mainColor will contrast with the L of this
1485     * @return a different packed HSLuv float color, based on mainColor but typically with different lightness
1486     */
1487    public static float differentiateLightness(final float mainColor, final float contrastingColor)
1488    {
1489        final int main = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor), contrast = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(contrastingColor);
1490        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((main & 0xFE00FFFF) | ((contrast >>> 16) + 128 & 0xFF) + (main >>> 16 & 0xFF) >>> 1);
1491    }
1492
1493    /**
1494     * Pretty simple; adds 0.5 to the given color's L and wraps it around if it would go above 1.0, then averages that
1495     * with the original L. This means light colors become darker, and dark colors become lighter, with almost all
1496     * results in the middle-range of possible lightness.
1497     * <br>
1498     * Calling {@code offsetLightness(mainColor)} is the same as calling
1499     * {@code ColorTools.differentiateLightness(mainColor, mainColor)}.
1500     * @param mainColor a packed HSLuv float color
1501     * @return a different packed HSLuv float color, with its L channel changed.
1502     */
1503    public static float offsetLightness(final float mainColor) {
1504        final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor);
1505        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((decoded & 0xFE00FFFF) | ((decoded >>> 16) + 128 & 0xFF) + (decoded >>> 16 & 0xFF) >>> 1);
1506    }
1507
1508    /**
1509     * Makes the additive HSLuv color stored in {@code color} cause less of a change when used as a tint, as if it were
1510     * mixed with neutral gray. When {@code fraction} is 1.0, this returns color unchanged; when fraction is 0.0, it
1511     * returns {@code Palette#GRAY}, and when it is in-between 0.0 and 1.0 it returns something between the two. This is
1512     * meant for things like area of effect abilities that make smaller color changes toward their periphery. This only
1513     * affects the saturation and lightness of the color; its hue and alpha are unchanged.
1514     * @param color a color that should have its tinting effect potentially weakened
1515     * @param fraction how much of {@code color} should be kept, from 0.0 to 1.0
1516     * @return a HSLuv float color between gray and {@code color}
1517     */
1518    public static float lessenChange(final float color, float fraction) {
1519        final int e = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(color),
1520                sS = 0x80, sL = 0x80,
1521                eH = (e & 0xFF), eS = (e >>> 8) & 0xFF, eL = (e >>> 16) & 0xFF, eAlpha = e >>> 24 & 0xFE;
1522        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(eH
1523                | (((int) (sS + fraction * (eS - sS)) & 0xFF) << 8)
1524                | (((int) (sL + fraction * (eL - sL)) & 0xFF) << 16)
1525                | (eAlpha << 24));
1526    }
1527
1528    /**
1529     * Returns true always; HSLuv colors are always in-gamut.
1530     * @param packed a packed float color as HSLuv
1531     * @return true
1532     */
1533    public static boolean inGamut(final float packed)
1534    {
1535        return true;
1536    }
1537
1538    /**
1539     * Returns true if S and L are each between 0 and 1; if valid, HSLuv colors are always in-gamut.
1540     * @param H hue, as an unbounded float
1541     * @param S saturation, as a float from 0 to 1
1542     * @param L lightness, as a float from 0 to 1
1543     * @return true if S and L are both between 0 and 1
1544     */
1545    public static boolean inGamut(float H, float S, float L)
1546    {
1547        return (S >= 0f && S <= 1.0f && L >= 0f && L <= 1.0f);
1548    }
1549
1550    /**
1551     * Returns its argument unchanged; HSLuv colors are always in-gamut.
1552     * @param packed a packed float color in HSLuv format
1553     * @return {@code packed}, unchanged
1554     */
1555    public static float limitToGamut(final float packed) {
1556        return packed;
1557    }
1558
1559    /**
1560     * Identical to calling {@link #clamp(float, float, float, float)} with 1f as its last parameter.
1561     * @param H hue; will be wrapped between 0 and 1
1562     * @param S saturation; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1563     * @param L lightness; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1564     * @return an HSLuv color with the specified channel values, wrapped or clamped as appropriate
1565     */
1566    public static float limitToGamut(float H, float S, float L) {
1567        return clamp(H - floor(H), S, L, 1f);
1568    }
1569    /**
1570     * Identical to calling {@link #clamp(float, float, float, float)} with 1f as its last parameter.
1571     * @param H hue; will be wrapped between 0 and 1
1572     * @param S saturation; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1573     * @param L lightness; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1574     * @param alpha opacity; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1575     * @return an HSLuv color with the specified channel values, wrapped or clamped as appropriate
1576     */
1577    public static float limitToGamut(float H, float S, float L, float alpha) {
1578        return clamp(H, S, L, alpha);
1579    }
1580
1581    /**
1582     * Makes a quasi-randomly-edited variant on the given {@code color}, allowing typically a small amount of
1583     * {@code variance} (such as 0.05 to 0.25) between the given color and what this can return. The {@code seed} should
1584     * be different each time this is called, and can be obtained from a random number generator to make the colors more
1585     * random, or can be incremented on each call. If the seed is only incremented or decremented, then this shouldn't
1586     * produce two similar colors in a row unless variance is very small. The variance affects the H, S, and L of the
1587     * generated color, and each of those channels can go up or down by the given variance as long as the total distance
1588     * isn't greater than the variance.
1589     * @param color a packed float color, as produced by {@link #hsluv(float, float, float, float)}
1590     * @param seed a long seed that should be different on each call; should not be 0
1591     * @param variance max amount of difference between the given color and the generated color; always less than 1
1592     * @return a generated packed float color that should be at least somewhat different from {@code color}
1593     */
1594    public static float randomEdit(final float color, long seed, final float variance) {
1595        final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(color);
1596        float H = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
1597        float S = (decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) / 255f;
1598        float L = reverseLight((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) / 255f);
1599        final float limit = variance * variance;
1600        float dist, x, y, z;
1601        for (int j = 0; j < 50; j++) {
1602            x = (((seed * 0xD1B54A32D192ED03L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
1603            y = (((seed * 0xABC98388FB8FAC03L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
1604            z = (((seed * 0x8CB92BA72F3D8DD7L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
1605            seed += 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L;
1606            dist = x * x + y * y + z * z;
1607            if(dist <= limit)
1608                return clamp(H + x, S + y, L + z, (decoded >>> 25) / 127f);
1609        }
1610        return color;
1611    }
1612
1613    /**
1614     * Produces a random packed float color that is always in-gamut and should be uniformly distributed.
1615     * @param random a Random object (preferably a subclass of Random, like
1616     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.random.LaserRandom})
1617     * @return a packed float color that is always in-gamut
1618     */
1619    public static float randomColor(Random random) {
1620        return hsluv(random.nextFloat(), random.nextFloat(), random.nextFloat(), 1f);
1621    }
1622
1623    /**
1624     * Produces a random packed float color that is always in-gamut (and opaque) and should be uniformly distributed.
1625     * This is named differently from {@link #randomColor(Random)} to avoid confusion when a class both extends Random
1626     * and EnhancedRandom.
1627     * @param random any subclass of juniper's EnhancedRandom, such as a
1628     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.random.DistinctRandom} or
1629     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.random.FourWheelRandom}
1630     * @return a packed float color that is always in-gamut
1631     */
1632    public static float randomizedColor(EnhancedRandom random) {
1633        return hsluv(random.nextFloat(), random.nextFloat(), random.nextFloat(), 1f);
1634    }
1635    /**
1636     * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards end by change. Both start and end should be packed colors,
1637     * as from {@link #hsluv(float, float, float, float)}, and change can be between 0f (keep start) and 1f (only use
1638     * end). Both start and end must use HSLuv. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors.
1639     * @param start the starting color as a packed float
1640     * @param end the target color as a packed float
1641     * @param change how much to go from start toward end, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to end
1642     * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and end
1643     */
1644    public static float lerpFloatColors(final float start, final float end, float change) {
1645        final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), e = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(end),
1646                hs = (s & 0xFF), ss = (s >>> 8) & 0xFF, ls = (s >>> 16) & 0xFF, as = s >>> 24 & 0xFE,
1647                he = (e & 0xFF), se = (e >>> 8) & 0xFF, le = (e >>> 16) & 0xFF, ae = e >>> 24 & 0xFE;
1648        float Hs = hs / 255f, Cs, Ls;
1649        if (ls == 255) {
1650            Ls = 1f;
1651            Cs = 0f;
1652        } else if (ls == 0) {
1653            Ls = 0f;
1654            Cs = 0f;
1655        } else {
1656            Ls = ls / 255f;
1657            Cs = chromaLimit(Hs, Ls) * (ss / 255f);
1658        }
1659        // Lch to Luv
1660        float Us = TrigTools.cosTurns(Hs) * Cs;
1661        float Vs = TrigTools.sinTurns(Hs) * Cs;
1662
1663        float He = he / 255f, Ce, Le;
1664        if (le == 255) {
1665            Le = 1f;
1666            Ce = 0f;
1667        } else if (le == 0) {
1668            Le = 0f;
1669            Ce = 0f;
1670        } else {
1671            Le = le / 255f;
1672            Ce = chromaLimit(He, Le) * (se / 255f);
1673        }
1674        // Lch to Luv
1675        float Ue = TrigTools.cosTurns(He) * Ce;
1676        float Ve = TrigTools.sinTurns(He) * Ce;
1677
1678        float H, S, L, U, V;
1679
1680        L = (Ls + change * (Le - Ls));
1681        U = (Us + change * (Ue - Us));
1682        V = (Vs + change * (Ve - Vs));
1683
1684        // Luv to Lch
1685        H = TrigTools.atan2Turns(V, U);
1686
1687
1688        // Lch to HSLuv
1689        if (L > 0.99999f) {
1690            return Palette.WHITE;
1691        } else if (L < 0.00001f) {
1692            return Palette.BLACK;
1693        } else {
1694            S = Math.min((float)Math.sqrt(U * U + V * V) / chromaLimit(H, L), 1);
1695        }
1696        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(
1697                          Math.min(Math.max((int)(H * 255.999f), 0), 255)
1698                        | Math.min(Math.max((int)(S * 255.999f), 0), 255) << 8
1699                        | Math.min(Math.max((int)(L * 255.999f), 0), 255) << 16
1700                        | (((int) (as + change * (ae - as)) & 0xFE) << 24));
1701    }
1702
1703    /**
1704     * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards end by change, but keeps the alpha of start and uses the
1705     * alpha of end as an extra factor that can affect how much to change. Both start and end should be packed colors,
1706     * as from {@link #hsluv(float, float, float, float)}, and change can be between 0f (keep start) and 1f (only use
1707     * end). Both start and end must use HSLuv. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors.
1708     * @param start the starting color as a packed float; alpha will be preserved
1709     * @param end the target color as a packed float; alpha will not be used directly, and will instead be multiplied with change
1710     * @param change how much to go from start toward end, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to end
1711     * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and end
1712     */
1713    public static float lerpFloatColorsBlended(final float start, final float end, float change) {
1714        final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), e = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(end),
1715                as = s & 0xFE000000;
1716        change *= (e >>> 25) / 127f;
1717        return lerpFloatColors(start, BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(as | (e & 0xFFFFFF)), change);
1718    }
1719
1720    /**
1721     * Returns a 1:1 mix of color0 and color1. All colors should use the same color space.
1722     * This is the same as calling {@link #lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} with a change of 0.5.
1723     * @param color0 the first color to mix, as a packed float color
1724     * @param color1 the second color to mix, as a packed float color
1725     * @return an even mix of all colors given, as a packed float color
1726     */
1727    public static float mix(float color0, float color1) {
1728        return lerpFloatColors(color0, color1, 0.5f);
1729    }
1730
1731    /**
1732     * Returns a 1:1:1 mix of color0, color1, and color2. All colors should use the same color space.
1733     * @param color0 the first color to mix, as a packed float color
1734     * @param color1 the second color to mix, as a packed float color
1735     * @param color2 the third color to mix, as a packed float color
1736     * @return an even mix of all colors given, as a packed float color
1737     */
1738    public static float mix(float color0, float color1, float color2) {
1739        return lerpFloatColors(lerpFloatColors(color0, color1, 0.5f), color2, 0.33333f);
1740    }
1741
1742    /**
1743     * Returns a 1:1:1:1 mix of color0, color1, color2, and color3. All colors should use the same color space.
1744     * @param color0 the first color to mix, as a packed float color
1745     * @param color1 the second color to mix, as a packed float color
1746     * @param color2 the third color to mix, as a packed float color
1747     * @param color3 the fourth color to mix, as a packed float color
1748     * @return an even mix of all colors given, as a packed float color
1749     */
1750    public static float mix(float color0, float color1, float color2, float color3) {
1751        return lerpFloatColors(lerpFloatColors(lerpFloatColors(color0, color1, 0.5f), color2, 0.33333f), color3, 0.25f);
1752    }
1753
1754    /**
1755     * Given several colors, this gets an even mix of all colors in equal measure.
1756     * If {@code colors} is null or has no items, this returns 0f (usually transparent in most color spaces).
1757     * @param colors an array or varargs of packed float colors; all should use the same color space
1758     * @return an even mix of all colors given, as a packed float color
1759     */
1760    public static float mix(float... colors) {
1761        if(colors == null || colors.length == 0)
1762            return 0f; // transparent, usually
1763        float result = colors[0];
1764        for (int i = 1; i < colors.length; i++) {
1765            result = lerpFloatColors(result, colors[i], 1f / (i + 1f));
1766        }
1767        return result;
1768    }
1769
1770    /**
1771     * Given several colors, this gets an even mix of all colors in equal measure.
1772     * If {@code colors} is null or has no items, this returns 0f (usually transparent in most color spaces).
1773     * This is mostly useful in conjunction with {@link com.github.tommyettinger.ds.FloatList}, using its {@code items}
1774     * for colors, typically 0 for offset, and its {@code size} for size.
1775     * @param colors an array of packed float colors; all should use the same color space
1776     * @param offset the index of the first item in {@code colors} to use
1777     * @param size how many items from {@code colors} to use
1778     * @return an even mix of all colors given, as a packed float color
1779     */
1780    public static float mix(float[] colors, int offset, int size) {
1781        final int end = offset + size;
1782        if(colors == null || colors.length < end || offset < 0 || size <= 0)
1783            return 0f; // transparent, usually
1784        float result = colors[offset];
1785        for (int i = offset + 1, denom = 2; i < end; i++, denom++) {
1786            result = lerpFloatColors(result, colors[i], 1f / denom);
1787        }
1788        return result;
1789    }
1790
1791    /**
1792     * Mixes any number of colors with arbitrary weights per-color. Takes an array ofr varargs of alternating floats
1793     * representing colors and weights, as with {@code color, weight, color, weight...}.
1794     * If {@code colors} is null or has no items, this returns 0f (usually transparent in most color spaces).
1795     * @param colors an array or varargs that should contain alternating {@code color, weight, color, weight...} floats
1796     * @return a mix of all colors given respecting their weights, as a packed float color
1797     */
1798    public static float unevenMix(float... colors) {
1799        if(colors == null || colors.length == 0) return 0f;
1800        if(colors.length <= 2) return colors[0];
1801        return unevenMix(colors, 0, colors.length);
1802    }
1803
1804    /**
1805     * Mixes any number of colors with arbitrary weights per-color. Takes an array of alternating floats representing
1806     * colors and weights, as with {@code color, weight, color, weight...}, starting at {@code offset} in the array and
1807     * continuing for {@code size} indices in the array. The {@code size} should be an even number 2 or greater,
1808     * otherwise it will be reduced by 1. The weights can be any non-negative finite float values; this method handles
1809     * normalizing them internally.
1810     * @param colors starting at {@code offset}, this should contain alternating {@code color, weight, color, weight...} floats
1811     * @param offset where to start reading from in {@code colors}
1812     * @param size how many indices to read from {@code colors}; must be an even number
1813     * @return the mixed color, as a packed float in the same color space as the given float colors
1814     */
1815    public static float unevenMix(float[] colors, int offset, int size) {
1816        size &= -2;
1817        final int end = offset + size;
1818        if(colors == null || colors.length < end || offset < 0 || size <= 0)
1819            return 0f; // transparent, usually
1820        float result = colors[offset];
1821        float current = colors[offset + 1], total = current;
1822        for (int i = offset+3; i < end; i += 2) {
1823            total += colors[i];
1824        }
1825        total = 1f / total;
1826        current *= total;
1827        for (int i = offset+3; i < end; i += 2) {
1828            float mixColor = colors[i-1], weight = colors[i] * total;
1829            result = lerpFloatColors(result, mixColor, weight / (current += weight));
1830        }
1831        return result;
1832    }
1833}
